tweet: That’s 10 P/E points of additional valuation. Absent these factors, the S&P 500 would trade at a 15x trailing P/E instead of 25x. Coincidently, 15x was the average P/E ratio for the market’s entire history prior to the current era. /3

So what about the payout ratio? If companies in the S&P 500 only paid dividends, the current payout ratio would be 35%. That would warrant a lower valuation than the current 71% when buybacks are included. /19

A simple way to demonstrate this is to regress EPS against the $ amount of earnings (both of which are published by S&P). If we do this for the pre-2004 period as well as the post-2004 period, we can see that the slopes are different (see scatter plot below). /16

You can see the sensitivity of the market’s fair value at different levels in the discount rate. At a 5.5% discount rate (1.5% RFR + 4% ERP), the current fair value for the S&P 500 is 25x (trailing EPS) at the current 70% payout ratio. /5

Many technical indicators can be a coin toss without proper context. The same applies to stocks: since 1928 the SPX has had 48 death crosses, but 3 months later it was up 58% of the time by an average of 5.2%. Context is everything. /2

The 1960s analog: Here, the correlation on a weekly timeline. Dark purple: The correlation between the S&P 500 and long-term government bonds. Light purple: The Barclays Agg. A changing landscape could be afoot, which makes the 1960s analog all the more interesting.

The chart below suggests that the 10-year CAGR peaked at 16% a few years ago and is on a steady descent to 4% in 2027. In fact, after the market’s torrid run, the SPX is already at the level that the CAPE model suggests it will reach in six years. /2

By that measure, the market could still double from here. That would put the SPX at 8000 when this is all said and done. When? The past two super cycles lasted 19 years (1949-68) and 18 years (1982-2000). So, perhaps 2026 or 2027. /4

I believe we remain firmly in secular bull-market mode, and I suspect that won't change until the S&P 500 reaches 8,000 (could that be in the next 5 years?). With inflation top of mind these days, it is worth remembering the economy of the 1960s. THREAD/1

The old model hasn’t worked in years, because the bond P/E climbed to 200x, while the equity P/E stayed in the 20s. Some people believe we might see a repeat of 1987 if yields continue to rise while the S&P 500 keeps climbing to new record highs. 2/

See that pink line going straight up past the SPX? I indexed bitcoin to the price of gold as of March 2020, which is when bitcoin’s latest rise began. This shows what might have happened to the price of gold, had it been the only game in town as a monetary inflation hedge. /14

Stuck: The P/E for the S&P 500 has hovered around 22x for a while. As the 10-year yield has zigged, the implied equity risk premium has zagged. At 2.78%, the ERP is getting down there but my guess is that if & when the 10-year starts to come down, the ERP may bounce back up.

Ready for some really long-term perspective? This chart shows the SP500 dating back to 1871. The big dips represent secular bear markets, the spikes are secular bull markets. Both can last years. Since 2013, my thesis has been that we are in a secular bullmarket. SPX
If the 1940s analog is the right one for today’s market, there may well be more life left in the rotation trade towards smallcaps and value and non-US stocks. SPX

Let’s flick back to 1941-1946, looking at the real SPX and real rates: The 5-year yield is a good reflection of policy intentions & inflation expectations. If the analog holds, real rates may decline more, driven by rising inflation expectations & a lesser rise in nominals.

COVID-19 & the market: How it started, how it’s going. During the early days of the COVID crash when the market was down just 20% or so, I wondered if the 9/11 analog was fitting since many assumed a lockdown would quickly reverse. How it started… SPX 2/

With the earnings picture improving, valuations should start to come down in coming months as earnings catch up to price. Once earnings join the recovery—usually a few quarters after the price low—P/E multiples should start to come down. SPX

The markets, being a discounting mechanism, seem to be looking past concerns about current COVID-19 trends and on to what will, hopefully, be better days for the economy in 2021 & 2022. Here we see that 72% of stocks in the SP500 made a new 4-week high last week.

The recovery in commodity prices: Where it falls within the commodity super cycle remains to be seen but, as shown here, a lasting rally in terms of time and price could take shape. The bottom panel shows the 10-year CAGR for the SPX Index vs. CRB. commodities stocks

Here, you can see that the recent gains on the value side haven’t come at the expense of the large-cap growth side. A rising tide lifts all boats and, with the market eyeing a potent fiscal/monetary cocktail, it’s understandable that the tape is broadening now. SP500

During the financial crisis the rotation from growth to value occurred around a double-inflection point: LTM earnings & the NY Fed’s Weekly Economic Index bottomed. So it’s not surprising that a rotation may be happening now. SPX earnings
New highs: Bloomberg’s proxy for the global money supply is making new highs again, which suggests to me that the market may not be far behind. SPX (1/THREAD)

The correlation between the global money supply & the SPX suggests that the correction underway will be of limited magnitude. The new high in money supply against a 7% correction in the SPX could be viewed as a bullish divergence.

P/E ratios will come down at some point but, as long as earnings start to recover soon, it doesn’t need to be at the expense of price: The market should be able to grow into its P/E. Take a look at the SPX during early-cycle recoveries:
It’s good to keep in mind that during secular bull markets—and this may be one—the market goes up 71% of the time by an average of 1.5% a month. bullmarket SP500

The chart isn’t perfect but you can see that while dollar-cost averaging comes close to replicating a buy-and-hold strategy (represented by the SP500’s long-term CAGR), fund flows (a proxy for market timing) lag far behind & are close to what you can earn sitting in cash. SPX

An important thing to keep in mind after last week’s reversal? 5% declines happen all the time. They may not be as sudden as last week’s drop but they are common. Here, a daily chart of drawdowns. Any decline less than 10% is often noise. SPX SP500

The SP500 corrected 8% in the span of a few weeks back in June. That served as a reset before it continued its advance. I believe something similar would be a good thing for the markets now, provided that it doesn’t do too much chart damage! SPX

2/ Here, the top 10 stocks in the SPX vs. the bottom 490, indexed against the pre-COVID19 all-time high of 3394 in Feb. If the SPX was made up entirely by the top 10, it would be trading at 4378 today.
Yes, there’s much handwringing over the market’s lopsided leadership but it’s a misconception that the broader market would be nowhere without the FANG stocks…1/ SPX FAANG

While most bull markets end with narrowing breadth, that condition can persist for a very long time. This chart shows persistent negative breadth during the second half of the 1990s despite a three-fold increase in the SP500. bullmarket SPX stocks

(1/THREAD) Sentiment: One might think, with the market erasing all its losses, that sentiment would have gotten somewhat lopsided, but it hasn’t. Here, flows into equity funds & ETFs & money market funds. equities SPX
Assuming that earnings are bottoming now or soon, valuations should come back down in due course & not at the expense of stock prices. stocks market stockmarket SPX

The breadth divergence for the SPX is still in place but starting to improve, with 74% of issues now above their 50-day moving average (up from 65%). It’s almost a given that breadth will diverge from time to time so divergence itself isn’t a bad omen.

The SPX: I think positives outweigh negatives so I’m still constructive on risk assets but my conviction is lower now than it was a few months ago when market history told a more consistent story. Now we’re at a fork in the road with what may be a more binary set of outcomes.

Bull or bear market? The policy response we have now is a big reason why I assume for now that the 1929 vs. 2009 chart will mean we’ll follow the more benign analog (2009), below. The current Fed has learned from the past & is flooding the world with liquidity. SPX SP500

Yes, long-rallying & much-watched tech stocks tumbled yesterday but let’s remember that while the 5 FAANGs make up about a 5th of the SP500, there is much more to the SPX than these companies. Sometimes their importance is overplayed, IMO. I will dive deeper on this next week.

If consensus earnings forecasts are correct, then even at a reduced payout of 70%, the fair value would be 3224 at 4.5% ERP, the level at which the SPX is trading. This shows how efficient the market is given current consensus earnings estimates. Discounted cash flow scenarios:

If this is an early-cycle bullmarket, the divergence between the SP500 recovery high last week & lagging breadth should resolve in a positive direction. If it turns out to be a top—as it was in February—it will be a warning that will become obvious only in hindsight. SPX

Here, a daily plot of the SP500. My best guess is that we are in the midst of a corrective a-b-c pattern that could retrace a third of the gains (down to 2800 to 2900), before the up-trend resumes. SPX

9/ This shows that the SPX is actually at the 65th percentile instead of the 92nd. And again, using the level of interest rates and an average risk premium as a proxy, one could argue that current valuation levels seem to be more than justified.

3/ Here, the percentage of issues above their 50-day moving avg. Surprise, surprise: I assumed the market breadth during bear market rallies would be less robust than early-cycle bull markets but there are many examples of strong breadth during bear market rallies. SP500
(THREAD) Could the huge rally since March 23 be just a bear market rally? And how would we know? Let’s take a look at history—and some charts. SP500 SPX stockmarket investing

This may be nothing more than a simple A-B-C correction that resets the market. That’s what the market did following the 2009 low. Three months after the low and having rallied 40%, the SP500 corrected 9% & retraced a quarter of the gains. A repeat would take us to 2950 or so.

…In 2009, the market decline was 9% after a 44% gain & it retraced around a quarter of the rally. A similar correction now would take the SPX down to 2950. To me, a correction seems plausible & even welcome now that everyone is on a “second-wave” alert with COVID19.

With the SPX now just 6% below the Feb. high, it’s well above the 14% drawdown in the ‘22 estimate. To me, that can only mean 3 things: Either the market needs to correct, the fwd earnings estimates are too low, or valuations will remain elevated due to Fed intervention.

At 2990, the SPX has retraced 66% of its decline, exceeding what most would consider the maximum 50-62% retracement that might still qualify as a bear market rally. (Exception: 1929-32 cycle.) Statistically, the odds are up that a new bullmarket is underway.

Looks like the market is pricing in a ‘V’ to me: Here, the market’s forward P/E based on EPS estimates for 2020, 2021 & 2022. The market is now betting that by the end of 2022, EPS will be back to pre COVID19 levels, seen in the purple line. earnings SPX

What’s happening with buybacks? Here, the YTD running total of announced share buybacks in the US, compared to previous years. It covers all US companies filing with the SEC, a larger dataset than the SP500, which is why the numbers in the chart may seem bigger than usual.

…If the SPX corrects further, it could bring relief to valuation. This chart shows that as of Wednesday’s close the market was in line with 2021 EPS estimates, but that’s assuming those estimates are correct. The drawdown of -17% lines up with the blue line (2021) at -16%.

How much more could the SPX correct? If we take out last week’s trading low of 2800, that could confirm a small double-top, targeting 2650 (the diff. between 2800 & 2950, subtracted from 2800.) My view is that we are probably in a trading range of 2600 to 2900 for a while…

11/ Noteworthy, because if the US is heading to a regime where the labor-vs-capital pendulum starts swinging toward labor, the payout ratio for the SPX will likely decline. This would, in turn, justify lower valuation multiples, as we’re already seeing in Japan & Europe.
This is just the SPX price index. I will post an update using total return.
This time, a similar pattern. Bears will argue that the recent gains are a money-printing illusion from the Fed. In gold terms, the SPX has retraced 40% of the decline, vs 62% in fiat money.

Gold bugs were out in force during the GFC, calling for higher gold prices & saying gains in the SPX after the March 2009 low were a “money illusion” created by the Fed. You could divide the SPX by gold to get an index denominated in “real” money instead of “fiat” money.

If it’s not THE low & we’re still in the GFC analog, we could be at the stage where the market peaked after the 2nd low: The 1st was Oct. 10, ‘08 at 840 & the 2nd was Nov.21, ‘08 at 741. The subsequent rally failed, leading to the final bottom of 667 on March 6, ‘09. data SPX

…Wondering: If the BCOM was able to do its natural technical thing unencumbered by QE or liquidity programs, is this what the SPX might have done without Fed action? And perhaps smallcaps, value & cyclicals will join in since they dance to the same tune as commodities?

After declining 35% in 24 trading days, the SPX is now up 35% in 27 days (from intraday low to intraday high). This looks very much like a V, or I need to brush up on the alphabet. The big Q: Is it sustainable given the economy (& earnings) may not have the same kind of recovery?

Technically, the SPX has so far rallied in a 3-wave pattern, leaving open the possibility that the advance from the 2192 lows might only be a 4th wave up and that we will still get a 5th wave lower. I’m not betting on it, but I respect the possibility.

The market seems to be pricing in a “U” or a “V” recovery. At 2830 the SPX is near the intrinsic value suggested by my “V” scenario (2900). But a U (2600) seems more realistic than the V which could suggest we have seen most of the gains for now.

When markets stage sharp recovery rallies like this one after major declines, inevitably momentum will swing from oversold to overbought. What happens next could reveal whether a new bullmarket is underway or whether the gains were just part of a bearmarket rally. SP500 SPX
The SP500 Index retraced 57% of its 35% decline in 19 days. Fiscal & monetary intervention have helped support the market but could dampen the strength of a recovery over time. My take:
How to value stocks in a crisis? Here, I share four potential scenarios for recovery—best case to worst case—in considering how things might shake out.   COVID19 SP500 earnings

…Worst scenario, bottom right: This assumes a slow recovery & permanent reduction in share buybacks. The financial engineering era would fall victim to COVID19. It produces a fair value for the SP500 of 1871, 45% below the all-time high & 33% from last week’s close…

A big bazooka: Clearly, the Fed’s move is a big factor behind today’s move but it’s likely there is also a lot of FOMO going on among bulls & bears who were using the “lows will be retested” playbook as a reason to wait for lower prices to either cover shorts or get long. SP500

What can we learn from earlier crashes? The secular bullmarket from 1982 to 2000 was rudely interrupted by the 1987 crash, which took the SP500 33% lower with a breadth thrust of -70%. A year or 2 later it was making new highs, which continued until the peak in 2000. COVID19

The equity risk premium, or ERP, is now about 700 bps, although it should be noted that the “E” in P/E, which feeds into the ERP, cannot be trusted. In all likelihood, what is currently a sub-13x forward P/E is closer to 15x. SP500

The forward P/E was down to 13.5x yesterday AM. That number is understated since the forward EPS is not known yet but will likely come down from current levels. But still, both the trading and forward P/E are down six handles from the peak. SP500 earnings

Much of the chaotic selling in recent days seems to have been driven by the risk parity crowd. Indeed, as we can see at the bottom of this chart, the declines there have been swift. SP500 marketvolatility stockmarket COVID19

A light at the end—or in the middle—of the tunnel? This was a rough week but the Fed and others realize the potential economic impact of COVID19 and are prepared to react, as the central bank did yesterday—and likely will again next week. stockmarket SP500

No question: The market turmoil we’ve seen in recent days is one we’ll revisit and analyze for some time. And the coronavirus will go down in history one of the big stockmarket disrupters—more so than we imagined early this month. SP500

Unexpected shocks, rampant fear: The first chart shows the SP500 index in 2001 indexed to the SPX today. As you can see, last week’s decline as the coronavirus spread was almost identical to its drop in the days following 9/11. But losses were quickly reversed. stockmarket

While the “R’ word would certainly grab headlines—like we need those!—and make people even more worried that the party is over, I think the market will look through what’s happening and that the price and valuation (and earnings) reset will be a one-off event. recession SPX

Market reset: One week & a 15% decline later, what can we learn from history? While the drop last week was swift, it wasn’t unlike other corrections of this magnitude, but with valuations at a lofty 19x fwd multiple at a recent high, it was a painful derailment. SPX stockmarket

Investors who think the market slide is a one-off valuation reset based on a repricing of when—and at what level—there’s an earnings bottom, may consider buying the SPX down 10% and selling bonds—@ 1.16%, the 10yr is at an all-time low. stocks investing
With the coronavirus spreading & infecting markets, how should investors manage risk? I wrote about that here:    investing SPX COVID19

Not so fast: Friday’s sell off & new COVID19 hot spots could suggest another corrective down-leg for equities as markets price in the possibility that a V-shaped post-virus recovery happens later & from a lower level than expected… SPX stockmarket investing

Financial repression & investor behavior: This shows the SP500 up top & periods of Fed QE in the bottom panel overlaid against the total return and the P/E ratio. The P/E ratio, especially, illustrates how financial repression by the Fed might affect asset prices…

It does seem to me that we’ve been in a secular bullmarket for most of 11 years and will be until proven otherwise. “Otherwise” could happen tomorrow but this view means the burden of proof for either over- or under-weighting the major asset classes changes. SP500 bonds

Seeing the tape unfold across the markets recently should remind us that, since the financial crisis, the path of least resistance for equities remains up and, for bonds, it remains down. After a 3.7% decline in the SP500, the index has recovered and then some. coronavirus

Given the swiftness of the 3-1/2-month 17% rally in the SP500, even a technically non-damaging 62% retracement back to the top of the old trading range (low 3000s) would amount to a 10% correction, in the process pushing the fwd P/E ratio down 2 points to a more reasonable 17x.

…With US equities priced for perfection (or at least a global earnings rebound), the risk is that the typical baton pass that tends to occur after an initial P/E-driven rally might fail to occur right away. SPX stockmarket

Virus outbreaks & global markets: With travel to China now curtailed, the coronavirus outbreak is bringing up comparisons to SARS in 2002. This chart shows the analog, highlighting EM earnings (vs. the US), the CRB Raw Industrials Index, the MSCI China Index & the SP500.

If the earnings & interest rate stories are intact, then it’s the lofty valuation story that leaves the market vulnerable in the short term. Good to keep in mind that corrections of 5% to 10% happen all the time. I could see the SP500 test the old range highs of 3025.

With yields remaining near historic lows, the equity risk premium for the SP500 remains higher than what might be justified by the low VIX and benign financial conditions—an important counter argument to the Schiller CAPE naysayers out there.

The SP500 is back in its pre-2018 trendline and if it stays there it will finish 2019 at 3268. If that happens, it will be a +32% year for the S&P 500 (total return), which will surpass the 31% return in 2013 as the best year post GFC. Pretty amazing.

As long as the SP500—or any market, sector—can generate enough dividends or free cash flow (which is partially returned to shareholders via buybacks), that could be enough to drive the market higher for several more years. That’s at the core of the secular bullmarket thesis.

The SP500 quickly caught up to its rising trend-line, which is north of 3200. The SPX is now trading near 18x on a forward EPS basis. Next year the market will need to grow into its valuation. We are seeing ever so slight inflows into equity funds & ETFs again.

The bears will say the market is whistling past the graveyard & that a major top is coming. In 2007 the SP500 ignored widening credit spreads & an inverted yieldcurve & trended in a straight line to a new all-time high in Oct. before plummeting 57% during the financial crisis.

SPX valuation: If the fwd P/E hits 18.5x or so that would amount to a 6% multiple expansion from here, likely into early 2020 during the seasonally strongest time of the year. Add 5% earnings growth and 2% dividends and it’s not difficult to envision a double-digit gain…

…If so, the central banks can retain their independence and US bond yields reset back to a 2-handle, there would likely be ongoing demand for income-producing strategies but not to stratospheric extremes and the SP500 could continue to churn out a 5% free cash flow yield.

What could we see next year? If 2020 EPS comes in at about $174, then at the current trailing P/E of 18.4x, the SPX would be at 3200 a year from now (+7%). In other words, earnings could carry the day—if modestly—even after accounting for the typical estimate drift.

But: What if the bear market has already taken place? With the SP500 just a percent or two from its all-time high, that may seem silly to ask, but globally, the stockmarket has been in a 21-month-long correction, both in terms of price, time & valuations.

Trying to determine when the next recession will hit & to what extent it will sack the stockmarket is a hot topic—and for good reason. After a 10-year quintupling of the SP500, the stakes seem high. But investors have been waiting for the “big one” for some time…

Looking solely at the math, equities should go higher in coming years as long as the mkt’s P/E ratio stays close to where it is now and earnings grow from here. How quickly depends on the numerator side (FCF) of the discounted cash flow model & the denominator (cost of capital).

A case for an ongoing bullmarket? With the SP500 at 3000 after 20 months of sideways, almost any good news could set the market on fire. Even just 5% earnings growth in 2020 could take the SPX to the 3200 range next year, assuming no valuation haircut…

It’s difficult to see a scenario in which the SP500 will be able to stage an upside break-out of its 20-month-old trading range anytime soon. Earnings growth is steadily slowing and we are reaching the time frame when 2020 estimates could start to come down.

…Will a 60/40 portfolio continue to deliver the upside of the SPX? I think so. The bond market becomes extremely convex the lower yields go so the lift in return from the 40 side of the portfolio could help protect investors against downside equity risks. bonds

We can all argue whether or not this is indeed a secular bullmarket and we won’t know if it is until many years from now. But this much is clear: This market cycle continues to look, feel and act like a secular bull market. If it holds, are we looking at a Dow of 70k-80k?

Pivotal: Q2 earnings season starts today. Five of the 11 key SP500 sectors could show year-over-year EPS declines due to trade squabbles & weakness in the global economy. Let’s pay attention to what companies say about the rest of the year.

The risk rally: Optimism about the outlook for trade and a supportive Fed is fueling markets, with the Dow, SP500 and tech getting a lift. Investors are eager for green shoots but any backtracking, of course, could mean more volatility ahead.

How might trade tensions crimp the SP500? Consider Brexit and valuations in the UK since June 2016. From this chart, it looks like we could see forward P/E hit 13x down the road. But I do think the US will do better than the UK given its free cash flow premium.

The trade war and investors: SP500 sectors with exposure to China are feeling the pinch this month but let’s remember we’re playing a long game. Tensions will simmer for a while—and boil over from time to time—but it’s in the interest of both countries to come to terms.

The UK stock market has done OK since 2016 but valuations have been pinched. The forward P/E for the MSCI UK index fell from 16.5x in mid-2016 to just 11.4x last December before rebounding this year to 13x. Could US valuations suffer if the trade war with China escalates?

With the SPX down 5% to last week’s low, the Shanghai Composite Index down 14% & the CNY near 7.0, the question now is where the strike prices are for the US & China puts, assuming they exist. What are those puts? And what will bring both parties back to the negotiating table?
…So what is the right multiple? 16x? 15x? Last December it bottomed at 13.x. I doubt we’ll get there but if trade tensions escalate, investors may demand more of a concession. SP500

So far the SP500 has dropped about 5% from its May 5 all-time high of 2,954 to Monday’s closing price of 2,811. That’s not too surprising considering the meteoric 26% rise from 2,345 since December 26 and a full resolution of trade issues was all but priced in.

The swiftness of the SPX rebound early this year fits perfectly with the little mini-bear analog I’ve shared. It is a simple average of the recovery from the lows in 1994, 1998 and 2011. If it holds, the market can still keep going up. Check it out:

The buyback effect: The bearish take is that the SPX is 400 points higher than it should because of EPS inflation.  The bullish counterpoint is that the free cash flow (10% of sales for the SPX) that drives most buybacks is worth even more than that difference.

Just 4 months into the year the SP500 is 40 points from its all-time high and 100 points away from 3000. We could get there in the next few months if things continue as they’re going. We’ll likely see a change in heart among bull-market doubters if the SPX hits 3000.

Have share buybacks distorted the stockmarket? I don’t think so. While they have inflated EPS by 15% & therefore understate the P/E by 2 points, even without buybacks the SP500 price index would be up 3.3-fold since March 2009 instead of 3.8-fold, according to my math.
The stockmarket correction in Q4 and rebound in Q1 were both dominated by changes in valuation, as you can see here, taking a look at the SP500, EPS and P/E year over year. data, dataviz

If we are going back to a slow-growth, low-rate regime, it’s possible that secular growers could retake the lead for equities and perhaps even take us into a 2000-style growth/value peak. The FANG index is already up 40% from the December low, twice as much as the SP500. tech

The 2800 level, for the SP500, is starting to give way. The market failed there on 3/4 but, after dropping 3%, it is back at that resistance level.  If we manage to go above it, then the momentum crowd (CTAs, etc.) might chase it even higher, forcing sellers to reverse course.

What will follow the deceleration in earnings growth in the first half of 2019? Earnings estimates for the year are about 5%. Below, a look at what happens to the S&P500 after peaks in earnings growth. I believe the market should follow the higher of the light blue lines.
…While it does look to me like the SP500 will close the year modestly positive, albeit shy of its average annualized return—there will be a fair amount of uncertainty between now and then.
Yep,  The SP500 can rally after these “baby bear” drops and this rally is on the longer, stronger side. Good piece. Thanks for including me.

Nice to see a more ebullient market, for sure. But I think it’s best to keep expectations a little low and appreciate the wins as they come this year. Why? Trade issues will simmer for a while—we’re seeing a containment strategy—and earnings growth is still slowing. SP500

Many of us may feel winter’s chill, but the stockmarket is warm right now. A responsive Fed calmed investors and stocks posted their best January in 30 years and the SP500 notched its best month in 3+ years following the dog days of December.

Catching the low: Was the December 26 low—when the SPX was down 20% & the LTM P/E ratio was down 30%—THE low or just A low? It’s hard to catch the bottom based on historical analogs, as we can see from this messy chart, which goes back to 1900. Each cycle is different. data

We learned in the secular bearmarket of the 2000s that 20% corrections sometimes turn into 50% meltdowns but, fact is, those episodes are unusual. This chart shows that sometimes a 20% decline like the one we just had can reverse faster than you can say “bear trap.” SPX SP500

Trade tensions with China play a big role in the market’s P/E re-rating this year due to the stagflationary impact this could have on the economy & corporate profits. Tariffs can cause prices to rise or profit margins to shrink and affect supply chains.

Earnings growth of 5% to 7% next year translates to a calendar 2019 EPS of $168 for the SPX (current estimates are for $173 and LTM is $158). Even at a lower $168, there could be downside risk if US-China trade tensions escalate.

Outlook is murky, w/trade tensions & not knowing where Fed will end up. But: a lot of uncertainty is already reflected by lowered valuations. Since Jan, market’s P/E ratio has fallen to 15.4x. In other words, investors are better compensated for taking on an uncertain future.

…We won’t know if 2019 will go the way of 1995 but we do know that a lot of bad news is already priced in by the 23% decline in the market’s valuation. That’s why a positive surprise, like the Fed slowing down its rate hike path, gives it a lift. SP500 economy stockmarket

The market is coming to terms with a slowdown in earnings growth and economic growth in general. The estimated yoy growth rate for SP500 earnings in 2019 has dropped from 12% a month ago to now 9.7% and it could dip to 5%. But now we know the Fed is watching closely.

While it’s true that the 3rd year of a presidential cycle is typically very strong for stocks, it may not apply to this one because the 2016 election produced a lot of front-loaded stimulus. SP500 stockmarket

We’ve had a necessary reset in the market, one we’ve seen before, in 2015 and 1994. With P/E ratio under pressure, there’s been 20% valuation reset with a 10% price correction in the SP500. I chalk that up as a win. A macro-oriented market doing what it should be doing.

I still believe 2019 will be a pivotal year for the US market. After a prolonged holding pattern, SP500 earnings should be back down to trend (7-10% growth), China should be back in reflation mode, and centralbanks’ policy divergence should be more in sync.

Earnings are peaking but still growing so P/E pressure hasn’t been enough to cause a bear market, merely a stalling of the bullmarket. The market can tread water before moving up again. SP500 stockmarket

A few days ago it looked like the SPX was ready to beat its January highs, but there are some headwinds. The USD is gaining strength and financial conditions remain on their tightening path. Now it seems earnings growth will  have a post-tax-cut cyclical peak of 24%.

While the SPX is comfortably back near its January all-time high, the same can’t be said for markets around the world. The MSCI World Index is down 6.6%. The DAX, down 7.3%. The NKY is down 6.4%. And the Eurozone Banks Index, crimped by Turkey and EM, is down 25%.

1/2: While the SPX has sagged just 6.2% from its Jan. high, the DAX performance index is down 9.5% & EM has fallen 18.8%. If it weren’t for the US earnings boom, the SPX might be looking more like the ACWI index, which is down 9.4%

I expect financial conditions to continue to tighten but don’t think it will be evident in the SP500 price index, which continues to benefit from the earnings boom. It will likely be manifested by a compression in equity valuations & more pressure on emerging markets. EM

Sell in May & go away? Looking at the SPX since 1970, the first 4 months of the year & the last 3 are generally much stronger than the June-Sept period. It’s not practical to turn over a portfolio every 6 months but for some investors it could be a time for modest adjustments.
After two years of synchronicity, global markets are de-synchronizing. This may not change until SPX earnings growth peaks later this year or in 2019.

Good to remember: When a market corrects a very lopsided advance, it can happen through price or time. We seem to be doing it through time. The earnings backdrop is a large bailout, if you will, for P/E levels that were too high in January. stockmarket SPX Dow

Is a new low for the SPX coming? At 2450, if it gets there, it would have a drawdown of 15% (from high to low), very much in line with the kind of trading range we saw from late 2014 to early 2016, when there were two 15% drawdowns—in 8/15 & 2/16.
